ResponsesInList.Title: Database - date field formatting
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm working on a tracking sheet that learners update each time they complete a criterion. I chose Database because it can be exported by the learner. Trying to put a form together that has the following layout: Title of activity Category 1 Criterion 1 date1, (date2, date3) comment Criterion 2 date1, (date2, date3) comment Category 2 Criterion 1 date1 (date2, date3) comment Criterion 2... The issue is that the date field is auto-populated with current date each time the Database is opened. As only one date field is necessary for the evidence, if a learner completes it with one date, the rest of the dates will be automatically be put in my Moodle regardless, which is not correct for the purposes of evidencing. Is there a way to make the date fields be all blank to start with or to have placeholders? Also, is it possible to export as pdf? That would be more suitable for exam bodies as evidence.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database - date field formatting
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know, there is no way to make the Date Field blank in Moodle Database Activity. One other way you might consider doing it is to have each entry contain just ONE Date, and then make a Radio Button or a Menu Field for the Category. Each user would just add a new record when they complete the step which would contain the date they completed that step. If you get clever with Groups (one user per group and separate groups), you can display each user's entries in the "List view" to see how many steps they have completed. Or you use the "Approval required" setting, and don't approve any entries to keep them "private" for students. You would need to filter by Student in order to see only one student's entries. You can use JavaScript in your template to "print" list views which would download as a PDF depending on your browser settings. There is a webinar and Moodle Academy course coming up in September on Moodle Database which may give you more ideas.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database - date field formatting
ResponsesInList.Text: I have encountered similar problems with the database activity. One possible solution, would be to set the date field up using a text field, rather than a date field. This isn't quite as attractive as you don't get the 'date picker' options, and you cannot do anything with the dates - e.g. sort by date (as people will enter them in all sorts of different formats), but it does overcome the issue of the field being populated when you don't want it to be.

ResponsesInList.Title: Text fields of Database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: The text area allows you to specify a format. That can be HTML, Markup or Plaintext. As far as I know the format is not tied to the field definition, but to the entry when the content is added. In general, when a new dataset is entered by the user, the format is set automatically to HTML when the user has the Atto or TinyMCE as the default editor. When the user has the plain textarea displayed, the format selection appears and the user can choose what he might enter as content in that field. If your plugin never shows the "hidden" field to the user, then you also should be able to automatically set the format to plain text and fill the content.

After that, students will be able to edit and delete (!) entries (depending on your Single template).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Option to set up a Database per student
ResponsesInList.Text: Assuming that I am understanding what you are asking, then yes, you can have 1 single database, but where the students only see their own entries and not other students. This can be achieved in a couple of ways: You can set 'Entries required before viewing' to something high like 50, and then 'Maximum number of entries' to something lower (e.g. 10) this means that they will never reach the number of entries that allows them to view other peoples. If I do this I add some CSS to the database to hide the warning message that comes up. You can set the entries so they have to be approved before being visible, but you then never approve any of them - this means the students will see their own, but won't see others. I expect it is possible to do this by tweaking the permissions of the activity, but I have never mastered this, so usually go for one of the above.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database fo CPD and/or RPL
ResponsesInList.Text:
Kia ora team, I've created a Database that can be used for collecting CPD points/hours. Video demonstration (3 min; no sound; apologies for the amateur production!) Scenario A given number [n] of CPD hours/points are awarded per year; with [n] being the maximum
number of hours/points that can be awarded for the year/course. For
the purpose of the example courses, I have set that number at 20 CPD
hours/points per year. I am not sure if this is a realistic number but
it was (somewhat!) easier for me to do the maths in my head when I was
working things out. üòÖ Students upload evidence of their CPD to [a database activity in] the course. The course teacher views the CPD evidence and decides how many hours/points the CPD evidence is worth. The student can be awarded a badge/badges in 1 of 2 ways: One-off: The student receives a badge after completing 20 CPD hours/points. Iterative: The student receives a badge for every multiple of 5 CPD hours/points. (N.B. "Points" can be replaced with "hours" and "CPD" can be replaced with "RPL".) Here are the 2x ways, depending on how often you want to award people for their CPD points. One-off : i.e. 1x badge/permanent record for 20 points Iterative : (e.g.) 4x badges/permanent records, each for 5 points and accumulating to 20. Workflow: One-off How does it work? Student uploads evidence of their CPD to a database activity in the course. Each item is a separate entry into the database. The course teacher (or equivalent role) views the CPD evidence. They
mark it as approved and then give it a rating. The rating indicates how
many points CPD each evidence item (i.e. each database entry) is worth. Once 20 points is reached, the student is able to view and open a page
resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge being awarded.
(Done this way because badge criteria does not include grade.) OR Once 20 points is reached, the activity is considered complete and the badge is awarded automatically on activity completion. The student receives a badge. The badge reflects 20 CPD points. The
badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of any future
course enrolment or unenrolment. Reporting The teacher can view the gradebook to see how many points the student has accumulated. The student can view their gradebook to see how many points they have accumulated. Cons The maximum number of points is 20. If a student is awarded 10 + 5 + 8,
then they will only receive a maximum of 20 points. The additional 3
points beyond 20 will not be 'counted'. Workflow: Iterative How does it work? Student uploads evidence of their CPD to a database activity in the course. Each item is a separate entry into the database. The course teacher (or equivalent role) views the CPD evidence. They
mark it as approved and then give it a rating. The rating indicates how
many points CPD each evidence item (i.e. each database entry) is worth. Once 5 points are collected, the student is able to view and open a
page resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge being
awarded. (Done this way because badge criteria does not include grade.) The student receives a badge. The badge reflects 5 CPD points. The
badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of any future
course enrolment or unenrolment. Then, After 10 points are reached, the student is able to view and open
another page resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge
being awarded. The student receives another badge. The badge reflects (another) 5 CPD
points. The badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of
any future course enrolment or unenrolment. Then, the same kind of set-up for 15 points and 20 points. Reporting The teacher can view the gradebook to see how many points the student has received. The student can view their gradebook to see how many points they have accumulated. Pros Students can receive rewards more frequently. Cons Students have to click on the Page resource to receive their badge. Settings Both¬† "one-off" and "iterative" courses: Groups The course will have groups, in order for students to be able to only see their own database entries. You can auto create groups. Use the option Group # and the limit of 1 member per group. There
is a 3rd party plugin available for auto creation of groups on
enrolment, but I have not used it myself. Course settings Course name: CPD points 2024 Enable completion tracking: Yes Group mode: Separate groups Course Activities and Resources Database (and Pages for the "iterative" course) Database settings Name: My CPD points Entries Approval required: Yes Allow editing of approved entries: No Entries required before viewing: None Maximum number of entries: None Ratings Aggregate type: Sum of ratings Scale Type: Point Maximum grade: 20 Grade category: Uncategorised One-off: Grade to pass: 20.00 Iterative: Grade to pass: 0.00 Group mode Separate groups Add grouping restriction: Group: (Any group) Activity completion One-off: Completion tracking: Activity completion with pass grade Iterative: Completion tracking: Do not indicate activity completion Example fields Date completed (date) Upload evidence (file) Details (textarea field) Link to course or site ( URL field) *CPD can be replaced with RPL if necessary. Permission change Permission changes to Database activity "My CPD points": View the total rating you received (mod/data:viewrating): +Student Then, differences as follows: Settings: One-off Badge Name: "20 CPD points" Description: "The recipient has completed 20 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Database activity Settings continued: Iterative Page x 4 (Page 1) Name:"Click here to be awarded your 5-point CPD badge" Page content: "Congratulations!" [Add further info if needed.] Page 1 Settings Restrict access Student must match the following Grade: My CPD points must be greater than and equal to 25% Hidden entirely Activity completion Show activity as complete when conditions are met: Student must view this activity to complete it. (Page 2, 3, 4) As for Page 1 BUT Restrict access Student must match the following Grade: My CPD points must be greater than and equal to 50% (Page 2) 75% (Page 3) 100% (Page 4) Hidden entirely Badges Badge 1 Name: "5 CPD points (1)" Description: "The recipient has completed 5 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Page 1 "Click here to be awarded your 5-point CPD badge" Badge 2 Name: "5 CPD points (2)" Description: "The recipient has completed 5 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Page 2 "Click here to be awarded your next 5-point CPD badge" Same for Badges 3, 4 - make sure they are connected to the correct Page. FAQ Why the additional step of the Page? Because a badge criterion can be activity completion but not grade. Why add Student to mod/data:viewrating? So that they can see the ratings they were given. Why groups? So that database entries can be only viewed by the student who made the entries. In order for the database entries to be rated, they must be approved. Why not display pages one by one? i.e. restrict access In case the student doesn't access the first badge before they are able to access the second badge. Could Teachers or Managers award the badges? If you want them to, yes, add them to the badge criteria. Why not have badges that are 5, 10, 15, 20 (rather than the proposed 5, 5, 5, 5)? Because Badge "5-point" and Badge "10-point "might look like a total of 15 points, when it is really a total of 10 points. A "20-point" badge could be a nice additional badge to round off the calendar year. Perhaps make the 20-point badge with no expiry date and the "5-point" badges could have expiry after a year. That way, badges don't become overwhelming or cluttered. Please add any comments or suggestions you have for improving this further. NgƒÅ mihi

ResponsesInList.Title: Open .PDF in New Tab from Database Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello from Upstate NY USA - I have a database activity with over 3500 different types of documents (.PDF, .DOC, .MP4, etc.) .¬† One field in the database is used to upload a file.¬† Does anyone know of any code or setting I can add so that when a user selects a record that includes a .PDF document - this document opens in a new tab and DOES NOT download .¬† We know about browser and widows settings that can be adjusted, but not all users can adjust these settings.¬† We want to for the database to open this in a new tab and NOT download it at all. I don't see any settings on the field type that allows this. Thanks in advance. Lisa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open .PDF in New Tab from Database Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: This can be achieved creating a new tab with an iframe and put the binary data into the url ifself. The following code sample demonstrates this for PDF files only in the single view: document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", (event) => { document.querySelector('#defaulttemplate-single a.data-field-link').addEventListener('click', (ev) => { const url = ev.target.getAttribute('href'); if (url.match(/.*pdf$/i)) { ev.preventDefault(); With small modifications this can be adjusted to other file types as well and also in the list view. Basically after loading the DOMContentLoaded event attaches an event to the first Anchor element with the class "data-field-link" when the link is clicked. This attached function checks the suffix of the url and by this guessing what content type might be expected. For a pdf it fetches the content of the file, creates an iframe in a new window and adds the content via the src attribute. Here you have the chance instead of providing a url, use a base64 encoded string. That works also for other elemens such as images or anchor links when you want to force a download that otherwise would just be displayed in the browser. To make this work in the list view, two things need to be changed: * The query selector for fetching the Anchor links must not include #defaulttemplate-single * Fetch all Anchors with querySelectorAll() Best regards, Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pulling Database Activity Data into external website
ResponsesInList.Text: Integrating data from a Moodle database activity into an external website, such as one built on WordPress, is indeed possible and can be accomplished using various methods. While I don't have specific information on whether this has been done in the exact context you're describing, similar data integration and sharing between platforms are relatively common in web development. Here's a general approach to achieve this: 1. **Expose Data via API in Moodle:** - Set up an API within your Moodle instance to expose the data from the database activity. Moodle supports web services, including REST and SOAP protocols, which can be used to retrieve data programmatically. 2. **Access Moodle API from WordPress:** - In your WordPress website, you can use server -side programming languages like PHP or JavaScript to make HTTP requests to the Moodle API. Libraries like cURL (in PHP) or the Fetch API (in JavaScript) can be used to fetch data from Moodle's API endpoints. 3. **Parse and Display Data in WordPress:** - Once you retrieve the data from Moodle, you can parse it and display it on your WordPress site. You can format the data as needed and use HTML, CSS , and JavaScript to render it in a user-friendly manner. 4. **Scheduled Updates:**

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using the FilterCodes Plugin in the List View

In the database activity as some others, filters only work in the description part or any text area field but not in other places. A possible approach to solve your problem is to hide the entry students shouldn't see with CSS and then make it visible for teacher with JavaScript . To do so, write something like this: 
```text
<script>


window.onload = function makeComment()


¬† {


if(document.querySelector("#usernavigation .editmode-switch-form").innerHTML.length>0) document.querySelector("#hiddenItem").style.display="block"


}

```

If you want it to work in the list view, you need to query for all the selectors (classes) and then best use the forEach() approach in Javascript to change either all the classes or you go a different way and inject a new definition for the class which hides the element in question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ideas for academic usage of database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Databases can be used wherever you have structured data. Some use cases are: Collect measurement data When you give the students teacher assistent rights for the activity, they can than easily download the data themselves. Of course, if it is simple data, you can also use a collaborative spreadsheet with an office application for this use case. Build a ticket system for requests of students or staff. Manage equipment you want to lend out. Let students write structured reports about a certain topic. Use it for concept mapping. You need to install a plugin for that. Be aware that export of multimedia doesn't work with the database activity.

ResponsesInList.Text: You can create a Flipgrid like activity. I have used it for students to record self-introduction videos. I have also used it to create a Facebook-like interface for online discussions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ideas for academic usage of database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: It is a pretty basic setup and is one reason I like the database module. I have a text area field, and the students record directly into it using the video recorder built into the Atto editor. I didn't turn on comments, but you could if you want students to ask follow-up questions. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Database Module Entry links
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes... so; if you load the "View single" tab you get a URL like this for page 1: https:///mod/data/view.php?d=10&mode=single and then page 2: https:///mod/data/view.php?d=10&mode=single&page=1 and so on.... Now let's say that you have 4 pages total and page three is unapproved... As a teacher with the right to see unapproved entries your &page=X would run from 0 (page 1) to 3 (page 4)... If I then grab the URL for page 4 (https:///mod/data/view.php?d=10&mode=single&page=3) and email that to someone without the right to see unapproved entries; they are going to get an error... For them there are only three pages in the database ( id 0 to 2)... When you add more entries to the database and have unapproved entries scattered throughout the database; things get even worse... If you send someone a link to the entry using the &page=X scheme you may well link them to a completely different page! So why use this "&page=X" URL method rather than calling the "&rid=X" for each page link?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: Re: Re: Re: Export data for a user
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, that plugin will allow you to create custom reports, but the student role cannot normally use it so you'll have to tweak the permissions. Regardless, you'll have to be good with sql queries and you'll need to get data from at least these 6 tables: mdl_data - info about all database activities. Contains the 'courseid', which can be cross referenced with 'id' in mdl_course mdl_data_content - the content introduced in each record. Contains one line per field. Cross reference 'fieldid' with 'id' in mdl_data_fields , and 'recordid' with 'id' in mdl_data_records mdl_data_fields - every field available in any database activity. Cross reference 'dataid' with 'id' in mdl_data mdl_data_records - every entry in any database. Contains 'userid', 'timecreated' and whether or not the record is 'approved'. Cross reference 'dataid' with 'id' in mdl_data , and 'userid' with 'id' in mdl_user mdl_course - all of your courses mdl_user - all of your users You might find this (awesome) ERD helpful: http://www.examulator.com/er/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: single header menu for database
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the modified preset. Warning: When you go to edit the list template to see how it's made, over to the bottom left, click on, Disable editor. If you don't, and you use the editors, you will break the layout as it will save table info in the header that has to be in the footer for this to look right, when you are looking at the list view. You then add one table row in the header that contains table headers¬† with the column names and any formatting info you want, such as your use of strong. In the Repeated entry area, you define and format one table row with a definition of what goes in each cell or column. You should also add a More link in one cell. In this case I added it to the Noun cell. It makes it possible to go directly to a single record in, Single view. To make each row more compact, I have left off the examples and images. That's what the more link is for, to take you to the single view so you can see the whole entry. NOTE: You need to edit this preset as you do NOT make use of you CEFR checklist field. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Database auto-linking (one to many?)
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, the 'Auto-linking' can only link to ONE entry. I presume that you are using a 'Teacher's name' and a text field for your auto-linking, and you have more than one entries with the SAME name field. It may not work as you expected. To work around this, you can try to only enter one unique entry for on teacher's name. In this entry, list all links to their courses. Each link can be one Database entry in the same Database (or any other Web page). Like this: 1. Teacher John Add Entry 0, in the text field, he enters "John", in the Textarea field, he will enter a list of links. 2.¬†Teacher John Add Entry 1,¬†in the text field, he enters "John's course101 intro", in the Textarea field, he will enter a long intro about course101. 3.¬†Teacher John Add Entry 2,¬†in the text field, he enters "John's course202 intro", in the Textarea field, he will enter a long intro about course202. 4. John repeats step 2 and 3 for all of his courses 5. Enable auto-linking to Database entry and all text 'John' will link to his¬†Entry 0 which can be the "Index page" or a "TOC(Table of Content) page". (You can also use a Glossary entry as the TOC, and enable Auto-linking to Glossary if you don't want to use the same Database template for TOC and Course Intro)

ResponsesInList.Title: Database Availability
ResponsesInList.Text: The database module provides 2 settings Available From and Available Until, which basically hide the activity from users if the date conditions aren't satisfied. This seems to duplicate the functionality of the (site-optional) Availability-Date conditions. Is there much objection to merging these 2 features so that the From - Until database setting is migrated to the core availability feature? It has been pointed out that availability is a feature that can be turned off at the site level. So I propose¬† to treat is as new feature on master, and to drop these 2 settings in favour of the Core Availability API. As part of the upgrade we could migrate the settings to the availability settings but it would require site admins to enable availability, but we should be able to highlight this requirement as part of the upgrade. My main reason for this is that it allows 2 ways for end-users to set up exactly the same behaviour, and for the sake of simplicity /reducing cognitive load, it seems that we should only offer one way of doing things. It was suggested some end-user feedback should be sought. Full details posted in https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-60927 M

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Total field
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, When you add an entry, the duration is calculated based on start and end time, then placed in a text field, timespent. It is shown as Spent: on the View single page. The duration is just the calculated result of subtracting the endtime from the start time. When you look at the View list the Total hours: entry is calculated on-the-fly based on the time spent of all the records shown in the column above. If you set a search criteria, the list changes and the Total hours: is recalculated to show the total of the current records being listed. NOTE: If you decide to use the preset and edit the templates, you will want to disable the editor, or you may get unexpected results when saving. Also, if the editor is enabled, much of what needs to be seen will be hidden.

Hi Stipe, I am not sure if I am fully understood what you are going to do, but I will try¬†to suggest some ideas. 
```text
Acceptance of presented documents needs to be logged and there should be an option to list all employees who accepted and list of employees who still haven't accepted list of documents.
```
 Add a Moodle Choice, then set: Allow choice to be updated=No Allow more than one choice to be selected=No Limit the number of responses allowed=No Option 1=Yes Show column for unanswered=Yes 
```text
List of documents is related to job title (job description).
```
 You can add docs to different¬†folders, each folder for one job title, then add Restrict access to the folder: You can add a restriction of a folder for each single user ¬†(you have to create a lot of folders), or by Department in their profile (much less folders): The easier way is by Group: You can add your users into group manually, or use Self-enrollment with Key to enrol users to Group automatically. You can also find heaps plugins which can group users automatically after they have enrolled into your course. https://moodle.org/plugins/?q=group ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You can also enable 'Completion tracking' Edit course setting > Completion tracking > Enable completion tracking = Yes. In each folder or File resource, tick "Require view' Then, you can see Who has done and Who has not from; Course administration > Reports > Activity completion. This is the easiest way, you don't need to create the 'Choice' module at all. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Listing database content horizontally instead of vertically
ResponsesInList.Text: Peter Evans: "Unfortunately if you edit the template a filter in Moodle will validate the code and muck it up but if you keep the code in a external document you can just paste it back in and all will be well. Does anyone know how or where to turn this off." Hi Peter, the first thing you should always do when entering one of the templates pages is to press the "Disable editor" button (unless the HTML WYSIWYG editor - which is really a bad thing there - is already disabled). Best practice is to have a development instance of the same Moodle version, where you maintain a copy of the life database activity. Do all modifications of HTML templates always within a real good HTML editor app - and never directly in Moodle's interface. When you are finished, just select the entire text in your external editor app, copy & paste it into the corresponding field of Moodle's template pages. Finally, press the "Save template" button to make the changes effective. Everytime you have changed something of the templates or fields, I would advise to go to the " Presets" tab and export as zip. In your life Moodle, import the preset zip you have exported from the development instance. Note that this process only works well as of the current 1.9.1+ weekly snapshot. Best regards, Robert

Does anyone know how or where to turn this off. One way to avoid this unfortunate but sometimes necessary behavior is to write the table with javascript . In the header you define a string variable to which you then add the relevant table parts from each section of the template and finally document.write it in the template footer. Something like: Header script: var strHtml=""; strHtml+='..'; // open table and header row Body script: strHtml+='..'; // data row; the template generator do the loop on this script command and you get all rows. Footer script: strHtml+='..'; // close table document.write(strHtml);

ResponsesInList.Text: The Date field comes with some characters: 1. It pre-filled with the current Date. If you are requiring other Date, users have to manually alter it. 2. In Moodle2x, whenever you update your entry, the Date automatically adds one day. The bug has been fixed now, but if you are still in an old version, please have a double check. 3. When you export your entries to a spreadsheet, the¬†Date displays as a serial number, which you have to use a formula to convert it back. To work around these, you can use 'number', 'text' ¬†or 'dropdown' (preferred) ¬†field to produce Date/Month/Year, if you need them all. Then, you can 'require' your fields. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting ##user## and ##timeadded##
ResponsesInList.Text: No tricks, either hacks or diy with sql query. It shouldn't be too difficult to hack. This should probably be best done in data_get_exportdata in lib.php. This function is called from export.php which transfers to it the field records. Then data_get_exportdata summons from DB the entry records for retrieving the field contents. But the entry records are precisely what you need for the userid and timecreated and all you need do is add these bits to each exportdata line in the loop. These bits of entry info (and others) are made available for import/export in the dataform plugin. But the dataform is still beta and the import/export is not included in the current version. It will be added to the next version in a couple of weeks, when its rewriting is completed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Help with permissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Here's our need. In a database activity, some users (let's call them A users) must be able to add an only one entry and edit it afterwards. To do so, we set the max number of entries to one and we set "Entries required before viewing" to a greater number. This way, a user A can never see all of the entries. Then we have B users that sould be able to see all entries, but in read-only mode. We created a custom role copied from non-editing teacher, but we cannot find a way to allow them to see all entries without editing permissions. Any ideas? Fran√ßois

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help with permissions
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Fran√ßois, Sorry, you have to alter at least one permission . Part 1: Edit settings: 1. Approval required=Yes 2. As you did: 
```text
set the max number of entries = 1
```
 "Entries required before viewing" ¬†= None. 3. Remove #approve## AND ##disapprove## from templates. As long as you do NOT 'Approve an entry', nothing will be available for the 'A users' (Student role) to view, they can only work on the ONE they entered. Part 2: Creating a new role based on non-editing teacher Edit THIS Database permission only, move ONE dot: Manage entries=Prevent Part 3: Locally assign role to THIS Database activity only Assign 'B users' to non-editing teacher Now, B users should be able to see all entries, but in read-only mode. Do you want to stop B user to 'Add entry'? If so, you can set: Write entries=Prevent HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Copying entries between groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Our college has 34 English classes (groups). We have a database of lessons for tutors who visit the college to access so that they know what to teach in any particular lesson . Once they have taught a lesson they then upload a file to the database and enter some information into the database. The question is this. When I set the database up initially I go select a group, enter the lesson information for that group, which includes an uploaded PDF file and some other stuff. I do this for 10 lessons for that group. Then I select the next group and repeat exactly the same process for the next group, with exactly the same information. For 34 classes I do this 34 times!!! There has to be a better way. Does anybody know what that way might be?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Copying entries between groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you collecting feedbacks from your tutors? Then, just use Assignment Feedback feature (Offline assignment), or use Moodle Feedback module. If you do want to use your database, you can enable comments, then you don't have to enter same info many times.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Copying entries between groups
ResponsesInList.Text: You can try the Dataform module. If I understand you correctly, the lesson info is the same for all groups. You can create a view for each lesson and put all the lesson stuff in the view template. Then tutors can add an entry in the desired lesson view and enter their feedback text and/or file in the entry. You can design the entry form such that it would identify the lesson automatically depending on the view in which the entry is added. With the activity in group mode, the entry will be automatically associated with the tutor group, or with the current group, if the tutor can access all groups. So you only need to create 10 views. You don't need to add any entries. The entries will be added by the tutors. This should save you a lot of time. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I set up the student can only read a certain entry?
ResponsesInList.Text: Not possible with the Database module. The Dataform module allows you to select the entry owner when you add an entry. This way you can add entries on behalf of your students. Then if you set the activity Max entries to 0 and Separate participants to Yes, students cannot add entries on their own and when they enter the activity they can see only their designated entry. You can also import the students entries from csv by specifying the entry owner as the student username or idnumber. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I set up the student can only read a certain entry?
ResponsesInList.Text: Solution 1: If you want a student can only see his/her own entries, simply set " Approval required =Yes", and don't add the tag " ##approve##"Ôªø into any template. Then, students will ONLY see their own entries and teachers can see and edit all fields, include the 'Grade' field. Solution 2: Set " Allow comments on entries=Yes ", then, your teacher can post Grade into a student entries. only the student who enter that entry can see the posted comments. Solution 3: You can also set " Ratings" , you can set rate permission by teacher role only. Above settings require students to add entry first. Solution 4: If you don't need student to add entry at all, deliver your grades by " Grade" . Solution 5: If you don't need student to add entry at all, but want to deliver your grade in a sort of form, set up an 'offline assignment', and upload your Word form files into each student's 'Feedback"(you can do this by a zip file quickly). Solution 6: If you don't need student to add entry at all, but want to deliver your grade in a sort of form, set up an 'offline assignment', and attach a " Rubric". HTH

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Anna, If you set the Edit the database setup Entries > Approval required to Yes, database entries will be hidden from all but the teacher/admin, until such times as you do approve the entry. Alternatives you can try: you can also set Entries required before viewing to 50, and as long as no one reaches that number of entries, they cannot see any entries. You can guarantee they won't reach that number by setting the Maximum number of entries to a lower number than the Entries required before viewing. I prefer the first method as it does allow the option of letting an entry be seen whereas the others do not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Calculated fields - saving a calculated result?
ResponsesInList.Text: You should have a designated field which you can update in the entry form. Notice that in the 'available tags' list in the add entry template you have a list of field ids which you can use for accessing the field and setting there the value. Suppose the designated field is a number field called Bmi. In the 'available tags' list you should see Bmi id - ||Bmi#id|| In the entry template you can add a button and set its onclick event to something like "setBmi();" Then if you define the setBmi function in the add entry template it can be something like: function setBmi(){ document.getElementById("||Bmi#id||").value= BodyMassIndex(); } Of course the user will have to click the button to update the field. If you want it to be calculated and updated automatically you will have to add an event listener to the field and that is a bit more complicated especially if you need to support different browsers. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: exxample database showing use of Javascript to automagically calculate field contents
ResponsesInList.Text: The Dataform uses for formulas the same moodle lib that is used by the gradebook formulas and you can find a list of functions (in addition to the standard arithmetic operators) at http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Grade_calculations . At some point I will add logical operators. A few tips for Dataform formulas: - The F index of an aggregation should be lower than the F index of the aggregated (e.g. F1 can aggregate F3 but not vice versa). - The aggregation works on subsequent formulas where ever they are and is neither limited to a particular column nor to a particular sub formula. So an aggregation such as %%F:=SUM(_F1_,AVERAGE(_F2_))%% should also work. - The '!' prefix of the field name inside the formula disables editing mode for the field tag in the formula. - You can aggregate in the table row level by using the entry id as the F index of the aggregated formulas (which will make the F indices unique per row). See illustration. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Want students to print their database
ResponsesInList.Text: The " database " in Moodle: Is it a real database that exists separate from the main Moodle database? No. The DB support for the Database module consists of several tables in the Moodle DB. A php script is obviously extracting that data out in the export function and writing it as an Excel and ODS format. So why is it hard amplify that so that it exports in some other format besides Excel or ODS? Excel and ODS formats and even CSV format are not that simple and require specialized php libraries. CSV is considered simplest but it is only an apparent simplicity. The content exported by CSV is simple text but the content that is stored in DB isn't always meaningful when presented as is in simple text. For example, the content of the time field is stored in DB as unix timestamp, and what you get in the export file if you don't convert that timestamp to a date/time string is not very useful. You can find plenty of disucssions about that down this forum. Another example is exporting the textarea content. You get all the html there which in a spreadsheet is not very useful, and you don't get the content of images, so you don't get everything which is also not very useful. And converting rich content to something that could work in a spreadsheet is not simple. Other formats are less simple than spreadsheets. The simplest of those is probably html as it could be "what you see is what you export". But there is still the question of what exactly to export. For you the content of the export should include only entries. Others may want to export also blocks if included. It is possible to write a script that would do that, but the development costs and further maintenance costs more. Someone needs to comission the work and the ongoing maintenance. In some cases, workarounds are actually preferrable to features because they are cheaper and more flexible. You can be the master of your workaround. The CSS approach in the Database activity is one such workaround.

ResponsesInList.Title: number field comma truncation
ResponsesInList.Text:
If you input a number with comma notation in a number field the result is truncated before the comma.¬† E.g. "9,000" becomes "9".¬† Even explicitly adding a decimal gets truncated "9,000.00" becomes "9" Looking at the php documentation all I can find is this: PHP doesn't handle strings like "12,300.2" correctly
by default. with more information not showing a that exact usage case: converting from strings so, is this a PHP bug (in that it doesn't handle it by default) or a moodle bug in that we didn't handle that usage case, or a user bug for not understanding the nature of floating point operations. the offending code seems to be a call to format_float in field/number/field.class.php and lib/moodlelib.php contains the function (although it's odd that a few qtypes define their own float)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: number field comma truncation
ResponsesInList.Text: Be careful. It is not that simple. The character used as the decimal place marker varies by language (it can be either ',' or '.'). Similarly the character used as the thousand separator can be either '.', ',' or ' '. Therefore, something like 1,000 is ambiguous. In some contexts that will be interpreted as 1000. In others as 1. Moodle language packs have to strings to tell you which characters to use, and there are functions format_float to output a PHP float formatted the way the user expects, and unformat_float to reverse that on input. That comes close to getting it right. But, in reality, even that is not perfect, because of places like¬†Qu√©bec, which is English-French bi-lingual. Those two languages have opposite conventions for how to write numbers, but one person living there will might input numbers either way. You can't win.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: number field comma truncation
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't win. Thanks, that's what I was actually hoping to hear- it'll save me more time of investigation.¬† I figured that localization was the cause. however, there might still be a bug, as (if I under stand FP) 9,100 should be truncated to 9,1 or 9.1 depending on your flavor, but it's getting truncated to 9

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: number field comma truncation
ResponsesInList.Text: There are two completely separate things here, which confusingly often look similar. floating point numbers in PHP notation, like 1.0 or 1 or 3.0e8. floating point numbers either input by the end user, or output to be seen by the end user, which in PHP terms are strings and depending on the locale are either like '1.0' or '1' or '300,000,000' like '1,0' or '1' or '300.000.000' In Moodle, you should always use format_float and unformat float when you need to translate between the two. When processing input, PARAM_FLOAT means a PHP-style float (that you might get passed directly behind the scenes from, say a slider widget). For user input you should ¬†use PARA_RAW then pass it for unformat_float. That is not perfect, but covers 99% of cases.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: number field comma truncation
ResponsesInList.Text: Do you know how computers store floating-point numbers? The way it works is nobody's fault, but wishing it was other than it is, is futile. As William Lu said, if you care about the sequence of characters that make up the number, not the numerical value, then you have to treat the number as a string.

ResponsesInList.Text: Anyone has ever used the 'Field ids' in 'Add template' view? What is for? Can't find any instruction from Moodle doc. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the 'Field ids' in 'Add template' for?
ResponsesInList.Text:
The field id tag is rendered as the id attribute of the html input element of the field. The number is the field id. So for instance, if you have in your activity a text field called Text and the field id happens to be 367, then the pattern [ [Text#id] ] will be rendered as field_356. If you inspect the html of the entry form you will see somewhere there something like 
```text
<input class="basefieldinput" name="field_367" id="field_367" value="" type="text"></input>
```
 which is the html input element if this text field. The tag may be useful for accessing the input elements in the entry form with javascript . For instance, you can add javascript that changes the background color of the input box when it has content. Of course, for this to work the javascript should reside in the template rather than the js tab because the the tag can be rendered only in the template. But if your javascript is complex you can put it in js tab and add to the template only minimal javascript the calls the required function and passes to it the tag, something like 
```text
<script type="text/javascript">// <![CDATA[


do_something_really_complex_to_input_element("
Text#id
");


// ]]></script>
```
 hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Expand Database/Dataform to replace other activities and resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, I really mean that. I posted details here: http://docs.moodle.org/dev/unify_all_activities_and_resources Currently there are many different kinds of activities and resources, with varying features, some of which would be desirable in other activities. For example, ratings could be used by students to give feedback on faculty-posted resources. Rubrics could be used in grading Forum discussions. The Allocation features of Workshop could be helpful in the Assignment activity. Some of these activities, like the Quiz activity, implement plugins for question types and behaviors, but these can't be used in other, similar activities. Yet, all of the activities and resources are just different variations on databases. It is easier for most instructors to use pre-constructed activities like the current Quizzes or Assignments, but these could be implemented as templated presets of a new, super-database activity. This is what is proposed in the linked page. Here is an example of what I would use it for: At the beginning of a course, we want to ask students what their objectives are for taking a course, and when they hope to achieve that objective. For example, someone might be taking a course to be able to get a better job, or to go to graduate school, or to solve a particular problem they have at work or in a hobby. With this super-activity, we would create a question: "What goal do you hope to reach by taking this course?" We would also ask "when do you hope to reach that goal?" The student could enter one or more goals and dates. When the date is reached, the student would receive a notification from Moodle: "On date xxxx, you said that you hoped you would reach goal xxxxx by this date. Have you reached this goal?" The student would then be able to click a link, return to the course in Moodle, and indicate whether they had reached the goal, or wanted to set a new date. We would use the resulting data to determine what goals our students have and whether or not they are reaching them. We would be able to work with our students identify additional steps they might take to reach their goals. We would be able to evaluate our course designs to see if they are applicable to help our students reach their goals. Here's another example. We include an Announcements forum in the "zero" topic of each course. We would like to be able to display the most recent post(s) within the course page, just below the Announcements forum link itself. Here's a third example. We ask students to post resources within courses to share with other students. We would like to enable ratings for these resources and automatically show the highest rated links within the course, as well as allowing students or the instructor to see the most recent unrated links. Here is a fourth example. An instructor asks each student to post a project using a spreadsheet. The instructor asks each student to self-evaluate the project using a rubric before submitting it. The "submission" criteria are set so that the attached file cannot be considered "submitted" until this self-evaluation rubric is completed. A fifth example: the college decides to standardize links out to video streaming sites as a new "type" of resource. An activity template is created that includes a custom video icon and accepts a URL to a video. The video will be displayed on a page within the course, with a forum below it that appears after the video has been watched. The activity is defined to be "completed" when the student clicks the link to view the video AND submits a comment in the embedded forum. The idea is to create a flexible Activity that would allow an instructor or course developer to adjust the parameters and create new kinds of activities without needing to code in PHP. Groups of related interactions could be easily combined into a single activity for convenience of student viewing and instructor grading. It would also allow plugins like the Advanced Grading plugins to be developed once and used with multiple Activities, since they would all really be the same activity with different settings. Ideally, a migration tool would allow existing Activities and Resources to be converted to this format. Is there any interest in having such a structure? We would be interested in helping to fund it if we can get enough interest from other institutions and from Moodle HQ to get the feature into Core.

ResponsesInList.Title: Entry workflow
ResponsesInList.Text: Entry workflow is undoubtedly one of the most desired features for Database module users. An enhancement is currently developed by Wiktor Wandachowicz and some discussion about it can be found down the Workflow support thread. More recent discussion was lost after the cluster crash in Nov, but it suggested that the enhancement should be completed fairly soon. Workflow functionality is also developed for the Dataform module. Here is an illustration of current functionality. Comments and suggestions are welcome. Entry workflow can be applied to a Dataform by adding an Entry States field and some Entry Access Rules as needed. The States field allows for defining a list of states and a list of transitions with permissions and notifications. Undefined transitions are allowed by default to users with manageentries capability. There is no limit on the number of states. Entry access rules allows for setting access control for entries with a certain content, e.g. entry state. So for instance if we want to prevent students from updating or deleting submitted entries in this workflow, we can add a rule such as the following: In the definition of the rule, the subset of applicable entries can be determined by selecting an existing filter and/or by adding search criteria. In this illustration the rule uses a filter that is set to find all entries in state Submitted or higher. Access is set in the rule's context permissions: Then in entries list the entry states can be displayed and set according to permissions. In this illustration the current state is green, permitted transitions are orange and other states are grey. Tea Cher who is the teacher and has manageentries capability can set all states for all entries: Joh Doh has 2 entries, one submitted and John can no longer update or delete it and the other is still a draft and John can update, delete or submit it. Jane Duh has 1 entry that has been submitted and reviewed and so she can no longer update or delete it. Hope all this makes sense. Comments and suggestions are welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restricting database activity to view only - date specified but not time
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, the restriction is applied at midnight, that is 00:00 on the specified day. There is probably no foolproof workaround. You can add javascript to the instance to prevent editing but javascript can be turned off on the client side. Submit a tracker request for future versions. Afaict it is not likely to be changed in released versions as it is not necessarily a bug. At any rate, it seems like a fairly easy fix which you can try to apply to your installation. Basically, change the date_selector in the module settings form to date_time_selector. So, in mod/data/mod_form.php around line 29, change $mform->addElement('date_selector', 'timeavailablefrom', get_string('availablefromdate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); $mform->addElement('date_selector', 'timeavailableto', get_string('availabletodate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); $mform->addElement('date_selector', 'timeviewfrom', get_string('viewfromdate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); $mform->addElement('date_selector', 'timeviewto', get_string('viewtodate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); to $mform->addElement('date_ time_ selector', 'timeavailablefrom', get_string('availablefromdate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); $mform->addElement('date_ time_ selector', 'timeavailableto', get_string('availabletodate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); $mform->addElement('date_ time_ selector', 'timeviewfrom', get_string('viewfromdate', 'data'), array('optional'=>true)); hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking from a list entry to the entry information
ResponsesInList.Text: If you have the latest version of the Dataform (currently available only from git ) there is a designated pattern for that: #{{viewlink: view-name ; link-text ; url-query ;}}# view-name : The name of view that is linked. link-text : The text of the link. Could be html but ';' or any html special chars that would contain ';' if entered in editor mode, cannot be used. A special link-text pattern allows for display theme icons, e.g. _pixicon:f/pdf: Download , _pixicon:i/edit:Edit etc. url-query : Url query parameters that will be added to the view url in the link. These are arg=val pairs separated by |. The args should be expected by the target view to take effect. The vals can be entry patterns. Example for displaying a linked icon that will open the entry in a view called Single: #{{viewlink: Single ; _pixicon:t/preview:Details ; eids=##entryid## ;}}# In earlier versions you can set the target view (the extended grid view in your case) as default More by clicking the button in its M column in the view list. Then the ##more## tag will point to that view rather than to the current view.

ResponsesInList.Title: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Occasionally, there is need to concatenate values from multiple rows in a query or subquery, like this query which shows which groups each user is in: SELECT firstname, GROUP_CONCAT(groupid) AS groups FROM mdl_user LEFT JOIN mdl_groups_members ON mdl_groups_members.userid=mdl_user.id GROUP BY userid; firstname groups Ray 1,2 Guest User NULL Note the "groups" field is a concatenation of a column from multiple rows. MySQL has the GROUP_CONCAT function for that. ¬†MS- SQL doesn't have a function designed for that purpose, so the common idiom is to use¬†FOR XML PATH(''). ¬†is there a Moodle DML function to do that in a database-neutral way? I've found many posts in this forum where people have been using GROUP_CONCAT, making their code not portable to Microsoft SQL and possibly others. ¬†If such a function doesn't exist in our library, should it be added, so people can use it rather than database specific code?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you think you need GROUP_CONCAT then it is probably a sign that you don't understand relational databases. GROUP_CONCAT is occasionally a useful hack in ad-hoc reports, but it should rarely be used for real.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: > If you think you need¬†GROUP_CONCAT¬†then it is probably a sign that you don't understand relational databases. I started to address that in my original post, and perhaps I should have. ¬†Certainly that's true when you WANT a relational data structure, such as in the business logic, so maybe 80% of the time that it's used, it shouldn't be. ¬†Then there's the other 20%, when it's not being used wrong. The other 20% of the time, when it's actually proper / okay to use in my opinion, fall into two categories, one when it's "acceptable", and one when it truly is the best way available.¬†Sometimes, it may be acceptable when both a) you're in the presentation layer and that's what you're going to end up with anyway, and also b) doing it in the query is ten times faster than calling a PHP function in a loop. ¬†A example of that would be as above, a list of users, one column of which is the groups they are in. ¬†If you're writing the UI page to show that (not a library for user info), I think that's acceptable. ¬†In that case, you WANT something easily human readable, you don't WANT a proper data structure any longer. Where it may be the best choice available would be if there were a class called user_list, which does not show the groups. ¬†You want to add a plugin to show the groups. Thankfully, class user_list does offer a method user_list->add_column() to add a cell to each row in the table. ¬†So easy enough to add the "user's groups" column, right? ¬†Except add_column() gets you one cell, for one value. ¬†The list of groups isn't a single value, so you can either a) have your plugin return the group list as one value or b) rewrite the exist user_list class to allow each cell to contain an array of values, which it will then concatenate in PHP, accomplishing precisely the same result with far more work. A particular instance of the above type of example that you are familiar with is¬†question_bank_column->get_required_fields() - it expects one field, so GROUP_CONCAT(tags) might be the best way to do it. ¬†The other option would be to get Tim involved in significant changes to how¬†question_bank works, just so you could have a column for "Used by these quizzes", or "has these tags". Wow I was long-winded in this post, but I don't feel like editing it to be shorter.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Time Spent on each page
ResponsesInList.Text: What I meant is that you will not find the data you need in any of the Moodle database tables. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I really need students not to see this!
ResponsesInList.Text: If you try the Dataform please download the most recent build from git at https://github.com/itamart/moodle-mod_dataform . You need to first create a Dataform activity, then export your data from the Database activity and import it into the Dataform activity. For import into the Dataform create CSV view (to distinguish from the deprecated Import view). The view allows you to specify the field patterns to import and the csv settings. Then you prepare the csv content and either upload it from file or paste into a textarea in the import form (especially convenient for testing the import content before importing many entries). After import you are redirected to the browse view to see the imported entries. If there are no entries the import failed for some reason which at this point is not displayed (hopefully this would be added soon). Now, you can import almost anything that can be displayed, including entry info such as userid, timecreated, timemodified etc. You just need to include the right pattern in the view template. The csv column name is by default the pattern name unless you define in the template a different name. The import form also allows you to set a specific name for each column in case your csv content is predefined and you don't want to change its column headers. The pattern for the entry owner is ##author:id##. In the Dataform settings you can select group mode 'Separate participants' so that each student can see only his/her entries. Also, set max entries to 0 and entry editing time limit to 0, so that students would not be able to add any entries by themselves or edit the entries that were added on their behalf. If you want to be able to edit entry owner when editing an entry, use the tag ##author:edit##. This tag behaves like the ##author:name## tag in browse mode but in entry editing it displays for managers a dropdown of all the course participants. All this is undocumented so if you need futher assitance just let me know and feel free to add to the module documentation at http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Dataform_module .

ResponsesInList.Text: A preliminary enhancement of the Dataform which was surprisingly easy to do. For example, the following is an illustration of Dataform-based attendance activity with push buttons for selecting present/absent for each participant, and a column that shows number of attendances for each participant and total in the column header. The formula tag that does the entry level calculation in this illustration: %%F1:=||Lecture 1:value||+||Lecture 2:value||+||Lecture 3:value||+||Lecture 4:value||%% The formula tag for the column total: %%F2:=SUM(_F1_)%%

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Roles override to change behaviour of a database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Can only submit 1 entry (new, no-repeat) set max-entries to 1. Edit certain fields in the entry Not possible in the Database module. In the Dataform you can add multiple views with different subsets of fields and make some views unavailable to participants. Participants could have a simplified view which displays only the fields they are allowed to edit. Managers would have another view with all the fields. Denying editing of some fields is also possible by setting the number of edits of the field to 0, in which case the field won't be editable for a participant while editing the entry. Participants can view only their entry In the Database module enable require approval and don't approve anything. This of course will prevent you from using the approve tag for approving entries for 'office use only'. In the Dataform you can achieve the 'view own entry only' effect by a designated 'group mode' called 'separate participant'. You are then free to use the approve tag for internal purposes. Notes With the entry comments as the natural candidate feature for this behavior. Afaict, not possible in the Database module if you don't want participants to see the comment, because if you enable comments they will be accesible to the participant. Possible in the Dataform by adding the comments only in the managers' view(s). Alternately, you could use the Moodle Notes engine. You don't have actitvity context there, so the notes are not specific to this Database/Dataform activity. But depending on your detailed requirement it could still work for you with the notes in the course or site (or manager) context. Revoking By unapproving and approved entry. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Roles override to change behaviour of a database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Can I remove the edit and delete entry right from a student? For starters do not add the ##edit## and ##delete## tags to the student view. But that in itself does not prevent editing and deleting by direct url. So you need to set the editing time limit in the dataform settings form to some number of minutes. For instance if you set it to 1, editing/deleting will be prevented after 1 minute from adding the entry. The default is currently 0 for no time limit but we should probably change that to distinguish 0 editing time from unlimited editing time. send a notification email that an entry has been edited/deleted and which one? This is possible by a specialized field but this filed is not included in the standard distro and not yet released separately. Can I remove the Current view dropdown for students Yes, simply remove the ##viewsmenu## tag from the students' view template. But sometimes it is useful to leave the tag there. The menu appears only if there is more than one visible view (for managers 'visible' includes hidden and disabled views). So if you have one view for students they won't see the menu. But if the menu is in the template managers will see it and would be able to navigate easily out of the view should they need to. And how do you prevent a student editing a particular field, so only admin staff can? Currently the only way is to not include the field in the designated view for adding an entry (assuming the entry is locked for editing soon after it is added). There is a special view type - editon - that may be useful for this as it is designed for adding one entry. Other ways are underway. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Roles override to change behaviour of a database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: View visibility currently has 3 modes: Visible and accessible by everyone (open eye). Visible only to managers but accessible by everone (open eye in brackets). Visible and accessible only to managers (closed eye). You can switch modes by clicking the eye of the designated view in the views list. Managers for this purpose are roles with managetemplates capability (by default editingteacher and manager roles).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modify records with fields from other records
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Piergiuseppe I see. Ok, with - http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Data_manipulation_API - you should be able to make your own queries. Using MySQL Administrator I observed how the database works. ¬†So, given two databases, one for the bookings (title and date) and another for the available dates (just dates) and no other databases in my moodle installation, I observe... Two entries in 'data' table in the real database with the 'id' being the identifier - in my case the available dates database in Moodle was '2' and the Booking '1'. In 'data_fields' in the real database the 'dataid' field is the foreign key to the 'id' field in the 'data' table to associate fields with databases - in my case, my 'available dates' had it's own 'id' of '3' in the 'data_fields' table. Then adding / removing some data reveals that in the 'data_content' real table the 'fieldid' attribute is a foreign key to 'id' in the 'data_fields' table and has another attribute 'recordid' which is a foreign key to the 'id' field in the 'data_records' table - which is a timestamping log sort of table. ¬†And the 'content' attribute of the 'data_content' table is the date as a string which appears to be the number of seconds since 1st Jan 1970. So... ¬†What you need to do is for one database lookup all of the 'content' for the 'id' of the database containing the available dates but by using the 'id' of the field in that database, in my example, '2' and '3' respectively. ¬†Once you have '3' you can convert all of the 'content' to dates and display. ¬†Then when the user selects and you want to remove the date from the 'data_content' table, first remove it's record in the 'data_records' table with the 'recordid' foreign key, then you can remove its entry in the 'data_content' using the 'id' you previously got. I realise that this is complex! ¬†The best way to see what is going on is to have a clean Moodle installation and observe the data in the tables I have stated with a GUI etc. as you perform your scenario. I hope this helps, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Database activity as library management tool?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Amir You have an interesting idea. I'm not sure whether the Moodle database module is the best tool to achieve this. It is a very primitive database. The Moodle database module is very usable in its current format - but with limitations. I don't know whether there are plans to change it into a fully fledged database design tool in the near future. It would be fantastic if that would be the case. Some people would use Moodle just for that! Ideally you want to be able to link to other information in the Moodle database (not the database activity). E.g. The learners' information. I don't think one can do that - but I stand to be corrected. You also want to be able to create more than one table and a many-to-many relationship. You would want a table for the 'books', a table for the 'loaners'(this could be the Moodle User table) and a table containing 'loans', just very simplistically. You want a one to many relationship between the books and loans and a many-to-one relationship between the loans and 'loaners', thereby creating a many-to-many relationship between 'books' and 'loaners'. AFAIK one cannot create any relationships between tables with the current database module. Again I stand to be corrected. Having said that, I think that you could possibly use it to implement a library management tool. In one way it can work similar to filterable spreadsheet. You would make the books' information central to the database. You can have a field for date loaned and date returned. You can have check box or radio button field to indicate that the book has been reserved. The problem comes where you have to indicate who has borrowed the book. You will have to use text fields here - you will not be able to select the name of a user already on the system. This creates the possibility of incorrect spelling, inconsistency and so on. The same applies to the name of the person that has reserved the book. If a student wants to see which books they had borrowed in the past they can simply do a search on their name.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Database activity as library management tool?
ResponsesInList.Text: There are more issues to tackle. For example, if more than one student reserves a book, there is no way to tell who was really first. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to create custom forms
ResponsesInList.Text:
Assuming your starting point is the default template, one fairly simple way is to add to the css template the following: div.defaulttemplate input{width: 100%;} This definition will make all input field elements inside the template stretch to the size of their container element. So, if the fields are organized in a table, you can set the width of the table cell to determine the width of the input field it contains. This method is, however, column sensitive, that is, the actual width of a table cell is the width of the widest cell in the column, unless you merge cells. A more fine-grained method is to enclose each designated input field in its own container, that is, a div element with some className, and add a css definition as the above for that particular class. Example: Given the following part of the add template hello: [ [hello] ] Enclose the hello field with the highlighted code hello:
[ [hello] ]
Then add to the css template the following (change the size as needed): div.defaulttemplate .myHello input{width: 20px ;} hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: One Database connection to other IP's
ResponsesInList.Text: You mean that you the database server is on a different server to the Moodle web server? Put the IP address in $CFG->dbhost in config.php (definitely not 'localhost'). ResponsesInList.Title: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry for my Huge ignorance, but one of the database fields is "number" and it says (quote) Number Stores a floating number. Examples: -1000 0 0.123 What does this mean? I don't understand and have never used this field

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: As opposed to integer which is confined to whole numbers (1, 2, 13 etc.), float allows for decimals and as such has a floating . (dot) which is floating in the sense that it can move along the number: 123.0 12.30 1.230 0.123

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah I see- so you it just means a number with a decimal point then? (I am a Word person not a number person!) What sort of use might that be in a database?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I suppose it may be useful if you want to record information such as height in feet. Using just whole numbers in such a case might give a very wrong impression (for better or worse).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: Fixed-point_arithmetic at Wikipedia Fixed point used in banking for example because floating point would be cumbersome/impractical. I think floating point is where you need to be as precise as possible (decimal to the nth term).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: This should probably refer to real numbers. Fixed or floating point number (not floating number) refers to computational representations of a real number. That is a programmers' view. For users, they are really just real numbers, that is numbers that can have not only integer but also decimal part. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_numbers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: what's a floating number?
ResponsesInList.Text: And while we're at it, it may be worthwhile to consider also complex numbers which can have not only real but also imaginary part.

ResponsesInList.Title: Why No Headers or Footers?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why No Headers or Footers?
ResponsesInList.Text: The labels header and footer may be misleading. These are not the page header and footer, but merely extra template sections , which may be used for adding static content before and/or after the entries list. One common use of these sections is in designing the list template as a tabular list. This could be done in html mode and would require a open table tag in the header section, a tr and td tags with the entry content in the repeated entry section and a close table tag in the footer section. It should be clear why such sections are not required in the other templates. In the other templates you can simply add the static content at the top/bottom of the template. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Entries import UI: request for feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Revisiting the UI and features of entries import (export soon to follow) I have come up with a preliminary design and I'd appreciate some comments and suggestions for improvements. The link to the import form is a "template tag" and may or may not be included in a view depending on preferences. Clicking the link opens the form on the same page (this may be ajaxed): The form is meant for import but it also allows for adding multiple new entries. That's like adding a new entry but plural. So you enter the number of new entries you want to edit, say 3, and submit ("import"). This opens 3 new entries for editing: But back to import. There is the CSV settings and import input which may be either a file or text. The text option basically allows you to enter the csv in the textarea and may be useful for quick adding a few simple entries. The importer may select to edit existing entries, in which case the csv should contain a designated column for entry id and each record should have its entry id. The importer may also select to open the imported entries for editing after import. This may be useful for small imports where the imported data is partial for this or that reason and should be amended manually. I suppose the important questions are with respect to importing (and exporting) rich content such as files or formatted content such as dates. Binary data (such as image files) may be imported/exported in csv as base64. This however, is likely to make the csv file unintelligible to the naked eye. So perhaps identifying files by name in the csv and uploading next to the csv file a zip of the imported files. Let me know what you think.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entries import UI: request for feedback

The import functionality serves first and foremost the course manager (in the standard database module it is hardcodedly restricted that way). It's effectiveness and efficiency become crucial mainly where the activity is used as a resource such that the content is entered only or mainly by the activity manager, or when it is used as a management or administrative application. I've done both. As an example of the first instance I've used the database activity in courses as a repository of examples of solutions to exercises of the types students where required to submit weekly. When building the repository, but also during the term, I occasionally have to update all or many entries. By many I mean dozens or even hundreds of entries.¬†I have all the examples in excel where I apply the changes efficiently and then generate csv and upload to Moodle. In the standard module I have to delete existing entries and upload new ones. This may break internal links (from forums and other areas). In the implementation proposed above I can update existing entries from the csv. Some other times I just want to quickly add a few entries without having to create a csv file to upload. Again the proposed implementation allows that. I guess you haven't used the database activity in a way which would require this functionaliy. But you may have some other related requirement which I could add.
