ResponsesInList.Title: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: In table such as mdl_quiz_attempts and mdl_assignment_submissions there is a field called 'timemodified'. That field displays what looks like random numbers, and not the date/time. How can one actually view the dat/time? Much help would be appreciated

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: All time fields in the Moodle database are stored in UNIX time format. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time There ways to convert this to a more human readable format using formulas in excel etc. or on-line converters like: http://www.epochconverter.com/ Jon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: oh right, never knew that thanx. but the million dollar question is if i run a query and pump the query into a csv will it display the proper time or the UNIX time?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: It will output as UNIX time. In M$ Excel you can convert Unix time to GMT using the following equation: =UnixTime / 86400 + 25569 You would then need to apply a date / time format to the field as this will return the date time in the excel time serial.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: What is the 25569 in that formula?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: The date value of Jan. 1 1970. See explanation of conversion e.g. here .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. Does Moodle store all dates using standard UTC time, or does it use the¬†time zone of the web server that Moodle is hosted on? In other words, if¬†the time zone on my server¬†is UTC + 1 will Moodle store all dates as UTC + 1, or are they always stored as UTC?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: The database activity stores entries time as unix timestamp which may be regarded as offset from 1/1/1970 UTC and timezone independent. The rest depends on your server configuration. From what I've seen so far, this seems the standard Moodle approach to time handling.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: So Moodle core stores the unix dates as per the timezone settings on the web server, i.e. UTC + 1 for a server in¬†the UTC +1 timezone? Have I understood you correctly?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: Not quite but only because I wasn't clear enough. Moodle core stores a unix timestamp which is indifferent to timezone. It is only on display that timezones may come to effect and for that displaying time in moodle should be done through a lib function which looks for site admin timezone setting or user pref. In site admin setting the default is server local time and you can select any time zone and do or don't force it. You can also use the default and config your server local time to a desired timezone.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. I think I understand! Moodle always¬†stores the offset from 1/1/1970 UTC, regardless of any timezones. Then the lib function handles the timezone conversions based on how the site admin has configured the Moodle site. If I create a form that requires the user to capture a date will those user dates be¬†saved¬†to the database¬†according to the timezone on¬†my server, or as the offset from 1/1/1970 UTC? In other words, does the Moodle lib convert the dates that the user captures into the timezone indifferent offset?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 'timemodified' field format
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle's treatment of user input with respect to date/time values may differ from module to module depending on purpose. In the database module, user input in the date field is converted to server/user timezone according to the admin settings before storing in the database. Suppose than that a user adds a new entry with a date field and enters the current date. Since the user input is converted according to timezone but the internal timemodified is not, this may create a 1 day difference between the entry modified date and the user's date input, under certain timezone settings, unless you force server time. Hope that clarifies more than confuses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Making entries unedittable once ratings period begins
ResponsesInList.Text: There are two components to editing: the edit form (add/edit template or view) and the editing icons (in the single/list templates or views). To begin with, when you reopen you can remove the editing icons from the single/list templates so that students won't be tempted to click them. That, in itself does not yet prevent editing because the editing view may still be opened by direct url. So you need to remove the content of the add template and put a message such as 'Entries can no longer be edited'. Then, even if students figure out the direct url to the edit view all they will see is that message and will not be able to change their entries. Even you won't be able to edit entries without an actual editing form. Whatever you do, remember that what you see as an instructor is not what the student get. If you want to get closer to the student's view, you need to switch role (on the course main page) to student role. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: It is possible to have a database with a field that is only visible to the teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: No standard way. As a workaround you can show the designated fields by css subclass of 'editing'. The idea is that teachers can turn block editing on, in which case, the body of the page is assigned the css class 'editing'. So if you set the designated fields to show only under the 'editing' class, teachers will be able to reveal them by turning block editing on. Of course these fields are still accessible to students in the page source, but if the information is not confidential, this is not a problem. I'm working on a plugin which will allow you to design more than one view (among other things) such that you could have one view for students without the instruction fields and another for teachers with these fields.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I copy a Database with it's content to another course?
ResponsesInList.Text: The problem with straightforward copying is that entry authors may not be participants in the new course. The standard way to copy the activity and its content is the following: 1. Create a preset of the database. 2. Export the entries to CSV or Excell. 3. Create a new database activity in the other course. 4. Apply the preset to the new activity. 5. Upload the entries from the CSV. This does not preserve original entry authors but rather you will be the author of all the entries in the new activity (which is fine if you where the author of the entries in the original activity). There may be a patch somewhere for what you want but you need to search for it. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Rethinking templates structure and design interface
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently there are 5 distinct view templates (list, single, asearch, add, rss) however users may want to omit some of these templates (e.g. omit single or asearch) or have more than one view of a certain type (e.g. two types of list). The current templates approach makes this practically impossible for the average user. Suggested improvement: A generic templates structure which will allow the user to determine and design the activity's available views according to one's own preferences. So, for instance, one may want to offer students to select from 3 different list views and omit the single and search views. The template placeholders may be defaulted to the list, single, search etc. but the single and search could be override and redefined as lists. Views could be switch to by a dropdown list in the main view tab. In addition views could be set to allow edit mode so that even list views would be editable (like quick editing in the gradebook or assignments). More details in MDL-26983 . Vote if interested. Proof of concept commences on 1.9 stable. Comments are welcome.

ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Helen thanks. I met you at Heidelberg. Debugging no errors. But in the server error.log there were a lots of errors -> see below. But I solved the problem and I hope this code will be added to the core module. I made a lot of tests. http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-5374 with this Wen Hao Chuang added a comment - 12/Feb/10 06:38 AM - edited Here at SFSU we are using Moodle clustering. We have one load balancer running squid, and then 3 application servers behind it. So this https is important to us for squid server. Our solution is actually pretty simple - adding a site setting under the "Site policies" for "Force https" as a checkbox, and it would be up to system administrators to check (or uncheck) this checkbox for the Moodle instance. This has been working fine for us. Here is what you need to do: (1) In /admin/settings/security.php At around line 63 (above // "httpsecurity" settingpage Add the following line: $temp->add(new admin_setting_configcheckbox('forcehttps', 'Force https', 'Force the application to always use https:// . ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Database deletion
ResponsesInList.Text: The key line is: aBulkAction.push(myList[j].cells[13].firstChild.href+'&confirm=1'); This assumes that the builtin delete tag (##delete##) is in the 14th cell (and the command goes to cells[13] because counting starts from 0). Also, the delete tag should be the only thing in that cell. Even a preceding blank space will prevent it from working. So here is a more robust version of this line: aBulkAction.push(myList[j].cells[13].getElementsByTagName('a')[0].href+'&confirm=1'); This will go directly to the first link (rather than first child) in the cell. Now you can put anything you want there as long as the delete tag is the first link. Give it a try and let me know if it worked.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adapt questionnaires
ResponsesInList.Text: Afaict checkboxes in the database are listed vertically by default. You can try implementing all 20 self-assessments in one database. If you want the students to do one section at a time, you can add the self-assessments gradually. So you start with one self-assessment and let the students fill it out. Then you add the fields of the second self-assessment and modify the entry form to display it but not the first one. In the single view you can display both. Then you add the third and modify the entry form to display it, and the single view to display all three. And so on. With a bit of css and simple javascript you can make the self-assessments in the single view collapsible and so easier to browse. Since all the assessments will be displayed in the single view, that view could be printed out into a single booklet of self-assessments. You can use css to remove the header and footer when printing. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adapt questionnaires
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't have pages but you can have hidden sections. You add all 20 self-assessments to the 'add entry' template and hide them by css. Then you add at the top a dropdown box with the names of the self-assessments such that when the user selects one the corresponding section will appear on the page. This will require some simple javascript and I can help you with that if you want. This way every assessment can be added as a separate entry (rather than all assessments in one entry) and all assessments may be printed out into one booklet from the list view. This method cannot prevent students from adding more than one entry for the same self-assessment. Also, javascript must be enabled in the student's browser. This whole thing is non-standard and quite complex. Just consider the number of fields you have to add for 20 self-assessments (there are shortcuts if you are willing to manipulate preset XML directly). Then you have to work out the templates and you can't rely on the default templates. For that you need to do some HTML, CSS and javascript. ResponsesInList.Title: record id hack
ResponsesInList.Text: In order to link together two database activities I use the moodle internal record id. In order to display this id on the screen I made a very simple hack that adds a tag to the template editor. Basically the hack makes ##mdlid## be replaced by the record id as stored in the moodle database (much like ##timemodified## works). This is a quick and dirty hack, I know, but it might prove useful to some of you. Here she goes: In mod/data/templates.php around line 236 add: echo '<optgroup label="'.get_string('other', 'data').'">'; echo '<option value="##mdlid##">'.'record id'. ' - ##mdlid##</option>'; echo '<option value="##timeadded##">'.get_string('timeadded', 'data'). ' - ##timeadded##</option>'; In mod/data/lib.php around line 953 add: $patterns[] = '##timemodified##'; $replacement [] = userdate($record->timemodified); $patterns[] = '##mdlid##';

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Filter database records according to Date
ResponsesInList.Text: Try this. Add to the footer section in the list template the following code: <script type="text/ javascript "> var today=new Date(); var myList=document.getElementById( 'itemList' ); var myRows=myList. firstChild .rows; for (var i=1 ;i<myRows.length;i++){ var endDate=new Date(myRows[i]. cells[8] .innerHTML); if (endDate.getTime()>today.getTime()) myRows[i].className='iamexpired'; } myList.style.display=''; </script> This code assumes that the table of items is called 'itemlist', that it has <tbody>, that the first row is a header row, and that the end date is in cell 8. Of course, you can select another name and put the end date in another cell, in which case simply change the corresponding parts of the code. The table should also be set to display:none so that it will be displayed only after the filtering. The code does traverses the rows in the display and checks whether endDate of a record is bigger than today, and if so it assigns the css class 'iamexpired' to that row. Now add to the css template the following class definition: .iamexpired{display:none;} Clear cache and try. With a bit of luck it will work. (P.S. goes without saying that all entries should reside in one table, but said just in case )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding ##user## into database field
ResponsesInList.Text: The token ##user## refers to an internal field that is maintained by the database module automatically. In other words, you just need to specify ##user## in the list or single-view template in the place you want to have it displayed. That's all. No need to have it on the Add Entry form.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding ##user## into database field
ResponsesInList.Text: This field is in the database, just it is not available in the same way as the fields that you defined. Exporting that info is unfortunately not supported at present. See MDL-16593 . It should not be difficult to hack your Moodle to do it for you, though.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding ##user## into database field
ResponsesInList.Text: An alternative to hacking the code is adding to the list view some commented out lines which when activated (and the others commented out and the database made unavailable to students) output the info in csv format which you can copy/paste to txt file and open in Excel.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding ##user## into database field
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes and sorry. This is not a hack but rather an alternative way to think about the list view of the database. Suppose that your database displays a list of person-hobby pairs such that the person is the one entering the info. So your database would have a hobby field and the name of the person will be displayed by means of the ##user## field. Now, typically the list view template would be set as a table and look like this (simplified): header <table border="1" cellpadding="5"> <tbody> <tr>

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Order of new fields
ResponsesInList.Text: It seems that at the database activity level the only way is to recreate the fields in the right order. Not much of an elegant workaround but provided that the data in the activity is export/import friendly you could use the preset for creating a new instance of the activity with the fields in the desired order. Create a preset, extract the preset. xml file (which basically lists the fields) from the zip, edit it and move the block of the new field to the desired position in the list, and then copy it back into the zip. Then create a new database, apply the preset and upload all the data from the original instance into the new one. hth

ResponsesInList.Title: Better solution (with a little dirthy workaround)

But (as often as possible) the solution was easier, than to think so: The field-limitation (width for single-view) does not influence the real image-size. So we limited it for 200px (get a fine rss-view) and delimited the width in single-view with the help of css (see image below). 2) To get a list of "best graded images" we a) override the local permissions for students (update database -> override permissions -> students -> rate entries "allow") and b) implemented the database-patch ( http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-15569 ) Unfortunately the patch don't allow to sort the list directly for grades. As a "quick and dirthy workaround" we once a week change the list-view-template to a list of names, image-url and grades, export it and after that go back to original state. It's not fine, but works. Maybe Anthony will give us a better patch to sort single-grades...? 3) We published the whole database in the database for database ( http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=57&rid=3759 )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tables descriptions and ERM diagram ?
ResponsesInList.Text: You might like to create your own diagram (The give a fish/teach to fish type scenario). The following commentary may be useful. moodle_er_diagram Creating an ER Diagram from the log generated at install time. Note that some of the table relationships in Moodle are not strictly relational, i.e. some tables may have multiple value fields and there may be missing primary/foreign key relationships. This will result in a diagram where a table has no link to any other table. However this process may still result in a diagram that is useful to understand the database design. This was done on a Windows/Xampp machine. And MySQL Workbench 5.1.18 Don't do it on any system with important data, it involves truncating (deleting all records from the log) This assumes the use of the My SQL database. It was done using the MyISAM back end. I believe it would work with innodb. Ensure that the MySQL install is set to write logs to a table rather than a file with the following line in the my.ini file log-output=TABLE Change to directory root of install lib\xmldb\classes\generators Edit XMLDBGenerator.php Change Line 66 var $foreign_keys=false; to read var $foreign_keys=true; Do a fresh unattended install of Moodle up to the point where you are asked for the admin password. Then stop login to mysql from the command prompt issue the following commands use mysql truncate general_log; select argument from general_log where argument like '%create table%' into outfile 'moodle.sql' LINES TERMINATED BY '\r'; on my xampp install the file was output to the directory server \mysql\data\mysql load the generated file into an editor do a replace operation to find every incidence of CREATE TABLE and replace with ; CREATE TABLE This will ensure that every statement is executed. The import into MySQL workbench using the File/Import Reverse Engineer Mysql Create Script In Workbench select Model/Add Diagram. Select all tables from the Catalog list and drag onto the diagram.Select arrange/Autolayout and then wait. With around 200 tables, it might take a while to layout the diagram. Even then you will probably want to move things around to make it easier to understand.

ResponsesInList.Title: Rows and Columns in Textarea field definition
ResponsesInList.Text: I've just spent a whole day faffing about with this issue before sussing it out: To input more than one line of text into a field in a Database Activity you use the Textarea field definition. This allows you to set the width (in columns) and height (in rows) of the text input box desired. When you use a small number such as 2 or 4 for the height in rows the input box is lost completely. In my naivety I assumed that 1 'row' meant 1 line of text input inside the box. Apparently not. Take a look at this account for what happens in most common browsers when you use 2 or 4 rows for the Teaxtarea field definition. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group as a database field ? /Links in a text field ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Mark What a good idea to have a homework database! I like it. You can try the following work around. Create a dummy user for each of your groups. This could be the name of your group, but you could give it any name really. Set your database groups property to 'separate groups'. Enter the homework activities being logged in as this 'user'. Now if anyone from that group accesses the database they will see those activies/records whereas they will be hidden from any other group. If you are logged in as yourself and enter an activity that will be seen by all the groups - use that method for activities assigned to all the groups. When you, as the teacher, look at the list of activities you can 'filter' it to show only the activities of one of the groups - or all the activities. You can use the Url field to have links to your Hot Potatoes. When you go to the list of Hot Potato quizzes and right click on the link of the Hot Potato you want to be linked, you can copy the link. Copy that into the Url field. Now you can access the Activity from the database record. Regards Marius

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I use¬†the database activity module. What I want is really simple: I created a database activity module¬†with two fields (Name and Age). I uploaded some value. With the code of Moodle can display all the data that I want (details, templates, etc ...). But if I want to assign, via script, the contents of a given record (eg "Antony" and "33") in two variables $myname and $MyAge what code should I use? I've seen looking the code of edit.php or view.php functions that are used and type get_records get_Fields etc ... How can I use them to get what I need?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Take the fields of a record in a table
ResponsesInList.Text: Domenico - You need to understand the relationships between mdl_data, mdl_data_fields, mdl_data_content, and perhaps mdl_data_records. I will simplify the notations here to give you an idea data.id->>data_fields.dataid (an instance of a database activity module can have one or more fields joined by the respective id and dataid fields), data.id->>data_records.dataid (an instance of a database activity module can have one or more records added to it), data_fields.id,data_records.id->data_content.fieldid,data_content.recordid (the content is stored combining the record and field ids - in other words the content for a particular entry's particular field. So, I would start by creating something like: $data = get_record('data','id',$dataid); // where $dataid is the id of database activity module you are working on $datarecord = get_record('data_records','dataid',$data->id,'userid',$USER->id); //get this user's entry $fieldidname = get_record('data_fields','dataid',$data->id,'name','Name'); //get the field record for the Name field in this database $fieldidage = get_record('data_fields','dataid',$data->id,'name','Age'); //get the field record for the Age field in this database $datamyname = get_record('data_content','fieldid',$fieldidname->id,'recordid',$datarecord->id); // get the content record for the Name field by the current user $datamyage = get_record('data_content','fieldid',$fieldidage->id,'recordid',$datarecord->id); // get the content record for the Name field by the current user $myname = $datamyname->content; //get the actual data from the content record $myage = $datamyage->content; //get the actual data from the content record This is obviously not the prettiest way of getting at the data but I hope that it helps to illustrate how the data is stored. Please note that I have not tested this code as it was written solely for illustrative purposes so there may be mistakes in it. In summary, you need to have the recordid and the fieldid in order to get to the content. Let me know if this is helpful to you. Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm trying to run a query directly on the Moodle database.¬† I want to return all the current students of a course.¬† I can see students are associated with a course through the mdl_course_display table, but this returns old students who were previously associated with the course too.¬† How do I filter these out so that only the current students remain? Many thanks to anyone who can help! Bryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Bryan, The table you are referring to mdl_course_display isn't used to display enrolments. It's used to remember the display state for the course, for example user 123 on course 2345 may have topic 2 visible and all the rest collapsed. An entry is only written to this table when a user visits a course on which they are enrolled. When they are unenroled the record still remains as it's nothing to do with enrolments and used purely for the display. I think what you are trying to do is determine course enrolments. The table you need to be looking at (I think) is mdl_role_assignments. Regards, Lewis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Lewis. I found the solution (courtesy of the genius of Enovation, Dublin), if anyone else is having the same problem - here's the SQL : SELECT u.username, c.fullname FROM mdl_user u, mdl_role_assignments r, mdl_course c, mdl_context t WHERE t.instanceid = c.id AND u.deleted != -1 AND r.contextid = t.id AND r.userid = u.id AND r.roleid = 5 AND c.id = {course code id you want to query}

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Not complete Genius. Adding AND t.contextlevel = 50 is necessary. Also, roleid 5 = student is an assumption you should check.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to automate file upload to database
ResponsesInList.Text: First you zip the files you want to upload, upload and unzip. You should have in the database a text field for the file name, say, fileName. Now you prepare a csv file with the list of the file names of the files you uploaded. For example: fileName file1.doc file2.doc file3.xls You import the csv file into the database. Then you add to the single or list view template or both, an a tag with the file path and the file name. For example, suppose your files location in your Moodle files is: http://your.moodle.org/moodle/file.php/3/docs/ You can add to the template the following html: ||fileName|| (|| stands for square brackets) and the link to the file should be displayed. You can also associate the link with a doc type image. So you add to the database another field (text or menu) for the file type. You add the relevant info to the csv: fileName,fileType file1.doc,doc file2.doc,doc file3.xls,xls Then you lookup the url of your moodle doctype pix and add to the html an img tag such as and if you used the same names for the file types as used by moodle it should show the proper file type image (e.g. for pdf) Hope this helps

ResponsesInList.Text: They are very good for adding functionality to the form such as validation or initialization. The ||---#id|| (|| stands for square brackets) is the id string of the html element of the field you added to the form, and it allows you to access the element and its properties. So suppose 'Zobrazovaci metody' is a text field and you want it to recieve the default value 'Analysis' when the form is opened for adding a new entry. ResponsesInList.Text: For both text and HTML Editor fields you should use document.getElementById(fieldID).value= By the way, in your template code you have ```text ... ||Id kazu|| ... ``` This code means that when the 'Identifik√°tor kazuistiky' field in the form is clicked it will be assigned the default value. ResponsesInList.Title: Can I time limit a user's edit rights on a database entry?
ResponsesInList.Text: HI I am constructing a database that will allow individual students to record statements about their achievements along with statements about learning targets. I am very impressed with the database module - I have constructed a working prototype very quickly, in just a few hours. But I would like to put a time limit on the editing of a record after it has been entered. I would to stop post hoc changes to the records. Forums have a time limit on posts so that you cannot edit them after about 30 minutes. I'd like to do the same with database records. I assume that there is no easy way to do this. My hunch is that one could write a JS script that hides the ##edit## field after a specified time delay (perhaps a day or so).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I time limit a user's edit rights on a database entry?
ResponsesInList.Text: Should be possible with javascript and should be fairly easy to hide the ##edit## icon in the view templates by checking the ##timeadded## against the current time. However, users will still be able to go to the add/edit page directly with the url. To block such attempts you can add to the Add template javascript that checks the time limit and if it has passed displays a warning message and redirects the page to the previous one. Now, for calculating the time limit you will need the ##timeadded## value which you don't have in the Add template. So you can add to the Add Entry form a hidden field (text field placed in a div with style=display:hidden). When the Add form is opened the javascript checks this field's value. If it is empty this is a new entry and so the javascript just assigns the current time (first open time) to the field and let the add attempt continue. If the value is not empty this is an edit attempt in which case the javascript calculates the time elapsed by comparing the time value in the field with the current time. If the time limit has passed the javascript sends the user back to the previous page (history -1). If not it lets the edit attempt continue. Now, you can either run the javascript after the form is opened in which case you'll have open time which may differ significantly from the timeadded value if the user takes the time to add the entry. This should not be an issue if the time limit is crude enough (e.g. a day or two). A more elegant way to apply the javascript but somewhat more complex is to add a listener to capture the submit event and do the form validation then. In this case the first open time will match the timeadded (or close enough). I hope that helps. Itamar

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Access [[DATA]] with php?
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is how I do that. For the list view template I have three js functions (listHeaderTmpl, listBodyTmpl, listFooterTmpl) stored in a js file located in the Files section of the course site. In each function I create and return a string consisting of a part of an HTML code for displaying the list of items in a table. So the header function returns a string containing the open tag of a table and the header row; the body function returns a string containing an item's row; the footer function closes the table. These functions are called in the corresponding template sections and their returned values are collected in a string which is then dumped into the innerHTML of a div element. In the header section of the template: Create an identified (by id) div element. In a script tag include the js file containing the functions. In a script block define a literal and assign to it the string returned by the header function (e.g. var strHtml=listHeaderTmpl()). In the body section of the template: In a script block add to the same literal from above the string returned from the body function; pass the song value to the function (e.g. strHtml+=listBodyTmpl(' SONG '). you can check the value of song in the function and decide whether or not to add the item to the list. If you don't want to add the item you simply return an empty string; otherwise you return the html of a table row, e.g. function listBodyTmpl(song){ var str=""; if (song!=""){ str=''+song+''; } return str; } How you pass the field's value to the function depends on the characteristics of the expected value. Simple string values shouldn't pose any problem. See my previous post. In the footer section of the template: In a script block add to the same literal from above the string returned from the footer function (e.g. strHtml+=listFooterTmpl()). Assign the literal to the innerHTML of the div element you created in the header section (e.g. document.getElementById('itemsList').innerHTML=strHtml;) I hope that helps more than confuses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to recover old userid after LDAP sync?
ResponsesInList.Text: Your problem resembles on of our problems in the past: when the username - which is unique and should stay unchanged - is changed¬†in the LDAP , Moodle "thinks" that there is a new user and it creates a new record for this user. ResponsesInList.Title: Using the Database module to replicate a 'gallery' environment.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Question time for you all. I've recently been investigating a number of tools to try and replicate the processes used in a physical art gallery, i.e. replicating the following process: 1. a Curator creates a gallery (i.e. a teacher sets up an area for assignments), which would be a template of, for example, three pictures (or other file types) and some descriptive text. 2. the Curator allocates Exhibitors (students) to the gallery based on class lists, which also happen to be imported from Blackboard. 3. Exhibitors upload files into their 'blank exhibit' within the gallery and add some descriptive text. 4. the Curator, other Exhibitors and Visitors can view exhibits in the gallery (a critical aspect is that all images/text for an exhibit can be viewed in one browser window for an exhibit wherever possible). 5. Exhibitors can leave peer review comments at other exhibits (reviews can be seen by the submitting and receiving Exhibitors and the Curator but nobody else). 6. one of a number of Critics (assessors) can assess each exhibit and provide marks back to the Exhibitor (numeric and textual), and these marks form part of their assessment. In an ideal world the peer reviews submitted by students could be assessed along with their own gallery exhibitions. The critical parts of this request are not so much around how pretty it looks, but far more around being able to peer review and critique work in a way that restricts others from viewing these critiques, except of course for teachers... After much soul searching it looks like the database module in Moodle is the best fit for doing this, due to setting up templates for sumbission, providing peer reviews and linking back to a grade book. The question is whether this is the best way to do this task within Moodle? I thought about using the Gallery2 integration but this is more about peer reviewing (and is not necessarily restricted to image files either), and I just can't get my head around the Workshop module. Any feedback welcome!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using the Database module to replicate a 'gallery' environment.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kim, This work was actually a part of a consultancy job I recently completed, and Moodle came perilously close to being perfect for the job barring a couple of issues (listed earlier in the post). Although I haven't got a site I can share I can talk about how I had it set up. First - create a database activity. Second - create a template that has (for eample) a title (text field), two images (two blank image files) and a description (free text field). Third - (optional) modify the 'list view' to not show images - keep that as uncluttered as possible - maybe just exhibit name. Fourth - tinker with the 'single view' to show each individual exhibit however looks best in your situation. Fifth - enrol some students, give instructions and away you go! Students can not only post images/text but also leave review comments and if desired ratings for each exhibit. You can also limit the gallery to one exhibit per user if required. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Database Module: Each learner Private DB?
ResponsesInList.Text: Why not make the student "staff" and the staff "student" (or staff without edit privileges) ? That is what we are currently doing for more than 1,500 students for the posting and maintenance of their webfolios. The solution involves the administrators of our institutional Moodle platform but we think it worth the time and delay (less than 8 weeks in our case, including summer vacations...). More than 500 students are already made "staff" and the only thing slowing us is the conversion of the already existing webfolios (from an html format in WebCT or a Word format in MS SharePoint). To have an idea of what I am talking about, you can access the auto-formation flash modules available to our students. It is in French but I am sure you will get the main point (you can skip the first two sections which are local to our institution). From the point of view of a student, when admitted (and for the duration of his-her studies) a template of folders (and sub-folders) is created and many Word (or whatever you decide) templates are made available to modify and populate this folders's structure. Everything is private between each student and authorized teachers. Also, the templates are so universal that students can backup locally everything and re-use it when they leave our institution. As you can see, we are adhering to the KISS philosophy (Keep It Sillily Simple). It is not glorious but it works!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does Null store in database

ResponsesInList.Title: Database Module - Re-approve updated entries
ResponsesInList.Text: I am getting ready to implement using a database to allow students to submit information to be seen by other students. Obviously I want the data to be approved before being posted. So far so good, however, if the student goes back in to edit the entry after it has been approved then they could potentially add inappropriate content. To prevent this, I think that the approval status should be revoked if the entry is edited by a non-teacher. To address this, I have commented on MDL-5581 and would encourage those interested to vote on it. To prevent entries from getting lost, I think there needs to be another sort option of Approved/Date Entered so that the oldest issues awaiting approval appear at the top of the list. I have also requested the capability to have the database module send an email to the teacher when an entry is add/updated. This would let teachers know when something is needing approval and is similar to the behavior of forums and assignments. It is listed as MDL-8377 in the tracker.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Database Module - Re-approve updated entries
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. I'm not sure if my experience is related to your point, but I have set up a research article review database for university students in which they find an article, get permission from a teaching assistant vis a vis the "appropriateness" of the article for review, do the review, get graded and then (hopefully), the review is approved and opened up for perusal by other members of class. The problem we seem to be getting is that although the teaching assistant has approved the article as being appropriate for inclusion in the database, she has not approved the actual entry by clicking on the "Approve" link. Nevertheless, the article is still released for class perusal even though oftentimes the student has not finished entering data in all the fields. This looks a little like the problem you mention. Being nosy, I might have looked at the record and I am wondering whether simply by opening up the record to look at it, I (or the assistant) have triggered the approval process. Obviously we don't want to have done this, so if we have, we want to be able to revoke the approval. Am I making sense? Rick Danielson

ResponsesInList.Title: How to replicate a database structure
ResponsesInList.Text: Log in as admin or teacher to the course containing the db. Use Backup (in the Administration block) to backup the database. You will need to back it up with user data (which I know is not what you want - but I believe or hope that folks are working on resolving that problem). You can Restore the resulting archive to another location, and then remove the user records from that restored instance (I know - laborious if you have a lot of user records). If you then Backup that new instance (which has no user records), again specifying that it's to be backed up with user data, you'll have a backup which contains just field and templates.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New to Moodle.  Please Tell me if this db module is right for my needs., PLEASE HELP
ResponsesInList.Text: I think you need the quiz module and the associated database filled with questions. That is not the same as the so-called database activity. I have not checked the quiz module for changes in 1.6 yet, so my following comment reflects 1.5.4. In 1.5.4 I found entering 300 questions (same type) so boring that I found an easier solution that could be helpful for you as well. Start from scratch in Moodle and enter 2-3 questions manually. Export these questions from Moodle to XML . Open this XML file in Notepad and look for the repetitive part with your 2-3 questions. This repetitive part consists of XML-stuff, your data, other XML-stuff, more data, etc. all together specifying a single question. Now create an Excel sheet with the XML stuff in column A, your data in column B, more XML in column C etc.; one row in Excel will represent a single question from your quiz. Next go to your old database, make lists with all the data you need for specifying your Moodle quiz. Copy/paste the data form your database in the appropriate columns of Excel, thus creating as many rows as you have questions. Copy the XML-stuff to all new rows. Copy the whole spreadsheet to the appropriate location in your Notepad XML-document. Import the extended XML document into Moodle. Maybe it sounds a little bit complex. However, especially when you have a large number of similar questions, it is a big time saver.

ResponsesInList.Title: Feature ideas for the Database module.
ResponsesInList.Text: I was chatting to some folk here who'd be looking at the Database module and found that it didn't do quite what they needed. I'm posting their requirements here for reference really just so that if anybody just happens to be looking for ways to improve the module at any point, they've got the information. Also, do let me know if any of this is actually possible already! These are the important issues: (1) Data input needs to be verified by user defined criteria.¬† For example if a student inputs a date of an observation, I want to check that the date is in the past.¬† I also need to be able to check that values are in certain ranges. (2) I need to be able to read the data from a program or application.¬† This could be achieved in different ways.¬† A live link to the actual table using ODBC.¬† But perhaps a simpler solution would be an automatic download from the table every 24 hours as a comma separated file, or some variation of this (i.e. just download records that have been added). (3) Moodle needs to be able to display ‚Äòlive‚Äô data.¬† For example I should be able to read my data table, create a graph or a map, copy that graph or map to some disk area which Moodle polls at least once a day and updates its website, so the students see the results of their data collection. (4) A nice touch would be entering data by clicking on images too. (2) and (3) would enable me to provide an autonomous solution.¬† I would write a program which I would schedule to run once a day, it would read the latest data, update its map or whatever, copy it to the Moodle update area and the students would see the results.¬† I really don‚Äôt think anything less than this cuts it.¬† Just imagine a long running project that collects data from all over the UK.¬† Can we really imagine that people are going to be happy to copy and paste data out of Moodle into their application and then go back into Moodle to upload some file.¬† I don‚Äôt think that will work in the long run.

ResponsesInList.Title: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any way to put entries the database and then search the entries in a "fuzzy" manner so that you get matches that are similar and not just matches that are identical (as in a google search, etc.)?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: Doesn't anybody have any idea about this at all?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: After doing a great deal of research it is gradually dawning on my just how complex my question was . . .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: The best way is to avoid using a database at all and instead use search engine technology, as seen in Google and Yahoo. The best open source contender is Lucene , a java application that is widely ported and integrated with other languages. At the moment PHP seems to be lagging behind other languages in their support for this technology, but the recent emergence of 2 seperate Web Service-enabled Lucene search engines may be the key to breaking through this barrier (though sadly this probably rules it out for most people running Moodle on standard commercial hosting, or at least increases the complexity greatly). Lucence Web Service API solr The second is more recent and more advanced. The most readable introduction to the relevant technology is the On Search series written by Tim Bray . However, given the lack of PHP-Lucene integration, and the portablity needs of Moodle it seems likely that lowest common denominator SQL methods will be the best available technology for the moment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks David. That's really helpful. I'd already tried to find something like Lucene but it is quite difficult wading through loads of stuff when you don't really know what you are looking for. It was quite an education though. Had no idea just how complex this technology was. The prices of some of the server -based search engine technology were also quite staggering. It was all news to me!
